title: George Macaulay Kirkpatrick
text:
General Sir George Macaulay Kirkpatrick (23 August 1866 – 6 February 1950) was a Canadian soldier who served with the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> in South Africa, Canada, India, Australia, and China. He became one of only a handful of Canadians to reach the rank of full General.
Education.
Kirkpatrick was born on 23 August 1866 to the politician Sir <a href="George%20Airey%20Kirkpatrick">George Airey Kirkpatrick</a> (1841–1899) and Frances June Macaulay of <a href="Kingston%2C%20Ontario">Kingston, Ontario</a>. He was educated at <a href="Trinity%20College%20School">Trinity College School</a> in <a href="Port%20Hope%2C%20Ontario">Port Hope, Ontario</a> and at the <a href="Imperial%20Service%20College">Haileybury and Imperial Service College</a> in London. He returned to Ontario to attend the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%20of%20Canada">Royal Military College of Canada</a> in Kingston from 1882 to 1885. As a surveyor in 1892, he authored <a href="topographic%20map">topographic map</a>s of the "Town and environs of the Fez Region of <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>".
Military service.
Kirkpatrick was <a href="Commissioned%20officer">commissioned</a> into the <a href="Royal%20Engineers">Royal Engineers</a> as a <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> on 30 June 1885. He was appointed <a href="Aide-de-camp">Aide-de-camp</a> to the <a href="General%20Officer%20Commanding">General Officer Commanding</a>, Thames District in 1892, and promoted to <a href="Captain%20%28BARM%29">captain</a> on 12 December 1894. He was deployed as Deputy Assistant Adjutant General (Intelligence) during the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a>, and received the <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> rank of <a href="Major%20%28British%20Army%29">major</a> on 29 November 1900. Following the end of the war in June 1902, he left <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a> on the SS "Canada" and returned to <a href="Southampton">Southampton</a> in late July. He served in <a href="City%20of%20Halifax">Halifax, Nova Scotia</a> as Deputy Assistant Quartermaster General for Intelligence from September 1902, and received the brevet rank of <a href="Lieutenant-colonel%20%28British%20Army%29">lieutenant-colonel</a> on 22 August 1902. Two years later he became Deputy Assistant Quartermaster General at Headquarters of the Army in 1904. He went on to be Assistant Quartermaster General at Headquarters, <a href="India">India</a> in 1906 and Inspector General of the Military Forces of Australia in 1910. He served in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> as Director of Military Operations in India from 1914 to 1916 when he became <a href="Chief%20of%20the%20General%20Staff%20%28India%29">Chief of the General Staff in India</a>.
He subsequently served as <a href="Commander%20British%20Forces%20in%20Hong%20Kong">Commander of British Forces in China</a> from 1921 to 1922 and General Officer Commanding-in-Chief, <a href="Western%20Command%20%28India%29">Western Command, India</a> from 1923 to 1927. He retired in 1930.
Honours.
Kirkpatrick was twice <a href="mentioned%20in%20despatches">mentioned in despatches</a> in 1902. He was appointed a Companion of the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Bath">Order of the Bath</a> (CB) in 1911. He was knighted as a Knight Commander of the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Star%20of%20India">Order of the Star of India</a> (KCSI) in 1917 and a Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath (KCB) in 1918.
Family.
In 1896, Kirkpatrick married artist Mary Lydia Dennistoun (1870-1945). They had three daughters, Georgina Helen (born 1898) and Kathleen Mary (born 1899) in Malta, and Margaret Charlotte (born 1904) in Canada, mother of <a href="Iain%20Tennant">Iain Tennant</a>.
